title: 114_s2855
content: The "Small Business Innovation Research and Technology Transfer Inclusive Outreach Improvement Act of 2016" amends the Small Business Act to coordinate efforts to increase outreach and awards under the SBIR and STTR programs for women and minority-owned businesses. The "Federal Agency Outreach Requirements for Women and Minority-Owned Businesses" is outlined in Section 3 of the Small Business Innovation Research and Technology Transfer Inclusive Outreach Improvement Act of 2016. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to implement an outreach program for small business concerns, specifically targeting women and socially and economically disadvantaged small business concerns. The Federal agency is required to provide outreach and establish goals for reaching these specific groups. The Small Business Act is amended to include an outreach program for women and socially and economically disadvantaged small business concerns. The Federal agency must provide outreach and set goals for reaching these groups. The Small Business Act is amended to enhance outreach efforts for women and socially and economically disadvantaged small business concerns in technological innovation and STTR programs. Additionally, an interagency SBIR/STTR policy committee is established. The SBIR/STTR Reauthorization Act of 2011 is amended to include provisions for the Interagency SBIR/STTR Policy Committee to meet regularly and discuss outreach and technical assistance activities. The Committee must invite a representative of the Minority Business Development Agency for meetings focused on increasing the participation of underrepresented small business concerns in the programs. The SBIR/STTR Reauthorization Act of 2011 includes provisions for the Interagency SBIR/STTR Policy Committee to meet regularly and discuss outreach and technical assistance activities. The Committee must invite a representative of the Minority Business Development Agency and relevant stakeholders working to advance the interests of small business concerns owned by women and socially/economically disadvantaged small business concerns. SEC. 6. DIVERSITY AND STEM WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT PILOT PROGRAM. In this section, "Administrator" refers to the Small Business Administration head, "covered STEM intern" is a student or recent graduate in STEM fields who is a woman or from an underrepresented group, and "eligible entity" is a small business receiving funds from SBIR or STTR programs. The terms defined in this section include "Federal agency", "SBIR", "STTR", "institution of higher education", "person from an underrepresented population in the STEM fields", and "pilot program" for the Diversity and STEM Workforce Development Pilot Program. The Administrator will establish a Diversity and STEM Workforce Development Pilot Program for internships for women and individuals from underrepresented populations in STEM fields. Key terms include "recent graduate", "small business concern", and "STEM fields". The Diversity and STEM Workforce Development Pilot Program aims to encourage the business community to provide workforce development opportunities for covered STEM interns through grants of up to $15,000 per fiscal year. At least 90% of the grant amount must be used for stipends or similar payments to interns. Evaluation of the program is required by January 31 of the first calendar year. The pilot program aims to provide opportunities for covered STEM interns through grants of up to $15,000 per fiscal year. Data on the program's results and an assessment of its impact on diversity in STEM fields must be submitted to Congress by January 31 after the third fiscal year. The program will terminate after the fourth fiscal year. Authorization of Appropriations for the pilot program.
